quotes.meaning: Arjuna's detachment (symbolized by letting sand slip through his fingers) mirrors the perfect focus of a warrior who acts without personal malice.
quotes.lore_snippet: The greatest archers understand this truth: the arrow flies truest when released without clinging. What is sand but earth made weightless? What is vengeance but duty unburdened?

quotes.quote: Dhritarashtra: Those whose fate is sealed by enmity need no lamentation, for destiny's wheel turns beyond mortal will.
quotes.sanskrit: अशोच्यं तु कुतस्तेषां येषां वैरं भविष्यति
quotes.meaning: Dhritarashtra acknowledges the futility of grief when conflict is inevitable, recognizing that enmity itself becomes a predetermined path.
quotes.lore_snippet: The blind king's resignation mirrors the Norns' threads—what is woven cannot be unwound. Warriors of Skyrim know this truth well: when blades are drawn, lamentations serve only the victors.

quotes.quote: Draupadi: When blood stains the bonds of kinship, even the earth trembles beneath such betrayal.
quotes.sanskrit: बन्धुशोणितदिग्धाङ्ग्यो मुक्तकेश्यो रजस्वलाः
quotes.meaning: Draupadi's disheveled state and bloody garments symbolize the desecration of dharma, where familial violence disrupts cosmic order.
quotes.lore_snippet: As the Draugr rise when ancient oaths are broken, so too do the realms shudder when kings discard justice for ambition. The Divines mark such transgressions with omens.

quotes.quote: Drona: The fire of vengeance, once kindled, burns twelve years in exile before returning as wildfire.
quotes.sanskrit: वैरं प्रत्यानयिष्यन्ति मम दुःखाय पाण्डवाः
quotes.meaning: Drona warns that repressed fury only grows stronger—the Pandavas' forced exile will forge them into unstoppable instruments of retribution.
quotes.lore_snippet: Like the Thalmor biding their time, or the Dark Brotherhood awaiting contracts, true warriors let patience temper their wrath. But when the hour strikes, none withstand the reckoning.

quotes.quote: Dhṛtarāṣṭra: Injustice, appearing as justice, does not depart from the heart.
quotes.sanskrit: अनयो नयसङ्काशो हृदयान्नापसर्पति ॥९॥
quotes.meaning: When one's mind is clouded by delusion, evil disguises itself as righteousness and takes root in the heart, becoming inseparable from one's nature.
quotes.lore_snippet: The greatest deceits wear the mask of virtue. When the mind succumbs to delusion, even the wise may champion injustice, believing it to be dharma. Such is the corruption of unchecked desire.

quotes.quote: Dhṛtarāṣṭra: The power of time is just this much—it makes one see things in a contrary way.
quotes.sanskrit: कालस्य बलमेतावद्विपरीतार्थदर्शनम् ॥११॥
quotes.meaning: Time's greatest weapon is its ability to distort perception, turning truth into falsehood and righteousness into wickedness in the eyes of the beholder.
quotes.lore_snippet: Kala (Time) needs no blade to destroy men—it need only twist their sight until they mistake friends for foes and poison for nectar. Even kings become blind before its power.

quotes.quote: Dhṛtarāṣṭra: They first take away his intelligence; he then sees things perversely.
quotes.sanskrit: बुद्धिं तस्यापकर्षन्ति सोऽपाचीनानि पश्यति ॥८॥
quotes.meaning: When divine forces ordain a man's downfall, they first cloud his judgment, making him perceive all things inverted—like a reflection in troubled waters.
quotes.lore_snippet: The gods need not strike down the doomed—they need only dim the lamp of wisdom until a man mistakes the abyss for solid ground and leaps willingly.

quotes.quote: Bhishma: The association with the wise purifies like water cleanses earth, but the company of fools is the very womb of delusion.
quotes.sanskrit: सद्भिश्च सह संसर्गः कार्यः शमपरायणैः। मोहजालस्य योनिर्हि मूढैरेव समागमः॥
quotes.meaning: This teaches that one's character is shaped by their associations - virtuous company elevates, while foolish company breeds ignorance.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient sages observed that men become like those they walk with. A warrior who keeps council with scholars gains wisdom, while one who frequents thieves learns their ways. Choose companions as carefully as you would armor.

quotes.quote: Yudhishthira: A ruler's true wealth lies not in gold, but in the love of those who weep at his departure.
quotes.sanskrit: धन्या वयं यदस्माकं स्नेहकारुण्ययन्त्रिताः
quotes.meaning: Yudhishthira recognizes that genuine leadership is measured by the devotion of one's people, not material possessions.
quotes.lore_snippet: The chronicles tell of kings who amassed great treasures yet died alone. Remember - a single loyal subject's tear outweighs a vault of jewels. Such is the economy of righteous rule.

quotes.quote: The company of nobles elevates one's spirit as flowers perfume the hand that holds them.
quotes.sanskrit: पुष्पाणामधिवासेन तथा संसर्गजा गुणाः
quotes.meaning: Virtue transmits through association, just as fragrance clings to those near blossoms.
quotes.lore_snippet: As the jasmine vine shares its scent with neighboring plants, so too do the virtuous impart wisdom to those around them. Seek the gardens where such souls bloom.

quotes.quote: Śaunaka: Day after day enter the fool, but not the wise man.
quotes.sanskrit: दिवसे दिवसे मूढमाविशन्ति न पण्डितम्
quotes.meaning: Fools are repeatedly afflicted by sorrows and fears, but the wise remain untouched by them through discernment and self-mastery.
quotes.lore_snippet: As the sage Śaunaka taught, foolish minds are like leaky vessels—constantly filled with new anxieties. The enlightened see beyond transient troubles, anchored in eternal wisdom.

quotes.quote: Śaunaka: Attachment is the root of all suffering, as fire born from kindling consumes the entire tree.
quotes.sanskrit: स्नेहमूलानि दुःखानि स्नेहजानि भयानि च
quotes.meaning: All grief, fear, and worldly turmoil arise from emotional attachment, just as a small spark can destroy an entire forest.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient rishis warned that clinging to possessions or relationships breeds endless sorrow. True warriors sever attachments as an archer cuts bowstrings—to strike freely at life's challenges.

quotes.quote: Śaunaka: Desire is an unquenchable fire within men's hearts, more destructive than any battlefield weapon.
quotes.sanskrit: तृष्णा हि सर्वपापिष्ठा नित्योद्वेगकरी नृणाम्
quotes.meaning: Craving is the most sinful force that eternally agitates mankind, growing stronger even as one ages, like an internal conflagration.
quotes.lore_snippet: The sages of old compared unchecked desire to a forge-fire—it consumes the fuel of happiness yet only grows hotter. Only wisdom's waters can extinguish this inner blaze.

quotes.quote: Bhishma: Contentment is the highest wealth; the wise perceive this truth while fools remain shackled by endless desire.
quotes.sanskrit: असन्तोषपरा मूढाः सन्तोषं यान्ति पण्डिताः। अन्तो नास्ति पिपासायाः सन्तोषः परमं सुखम्॥
quotes.meaning: True happiness lies in contentment, not in the ceaseless pursuit of desires which can never be fully satisfied.
quotes.lore_snippet: The sages of old taught that a single drop of water suffices for a thirsty man, yet an ocean cannot quench greed. Seek fulfillment within, not in the hoarding of worldly things.

quotes.quote: Yudhishthira: Share with the suffering—give beds to the weary, seats to the tired, water to the thirsty, and food to the hungry.
quotes.sanskrit: देयमार्तस्य शयनं स्थितश्रान्तस्य चासनम्। तृषितस्य च पानीयं क्षुधितस्य च भोजनम्॥
quotes.meaning: Hospitality and compassion are sacred duties; true dharma manifests in alleviating others' suffering.
quotes.lore_snippet: A householder's fire altar is not just for rituals—it burns brightest when kindled by generosity. The greatest offerings are shelter, sustenance, and kindness to those in need.

quotes.quote: The senses are wild horses; an undisciplined mind becomes their helpless charioteer, dragged into ruin.
quotes.sanskrit: ह्रियते बुध्यमानोऽपि नरो हारिभिरिन्द्रियैः। विमूढसञ्ज्ञो दुष्टाश्वैरुद्भ्रान्तैरिव सारथिः॥
quotes.meaning: Without self-control, even the wise fall prey to sensory attachments, tumbling like a moth into the flame of desire.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient scrolls warn that untamed senses lead men astray as surely as storm winds divert ships. Mastery begins when the reins of will tighten.

quotes.quote: Dharma Raja Yudhishthira: By controlling the senses, mastering vows, serving the wise, and restraining the mind, one conquers the cycle of existence.
quotes.sanskrit: सम्यक्चेन्द्रियनिग्रहात् सम्यग्व्रतविशेषाच्च सम्यक्च गुरुसेवनात् सम्यक्चित्तनिरोधनात्
quotes.meaning: The path to liberation lies in disciplined living, reverence for teachers, and mental control—essential practices to transcend worldly suffering.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient sages teach that mastery over desire and thought is the true armor of a warrior. Those who tame their senses walk the path of the immortals.

quotes.quote: The sun, father of all beings, sustains life through sacrifice—his light nourishes the earth like a king uplifts his people through righteous duty.
quotes.sanskrit: पितैष सर्वभूतानां तस्मात्तं शरणं व्रज
quotes.meaning: The cyclical generosity of the sun mirrors the dharma of rulers: to protect and nourish through selfless action.
quotes.lore_snippet: As the sun's rays feed the crops without expectation, so must leaders serve their people. This is the law written in the sky since time began.

quotes.quote: Dharma is both path and destination—those purified by right action and austerity become bridges across calamity, as mountains span rivers.
quotes.sanskrit: तप आस्थाय धर्मेण द्विजातीन्भर भारत
quotes.meaning: Sustained spiritual practice transforms individuals into pillars that uphold society during trials.
quotes.lore_snippet: Legends speak of kings who bore their people's suffering through meditation. Such is the power of tapas—to turn flesh into unshakable stone.

quotes.quote: Vidura: The threefold path is rooted in dharma, O king. This kingdom is said to be founded upon dharma. Abide by dharma according to your power, and protect all your sons and Kunti's sons alike.
quotes.sanskrit: त्रिवर्गोऽयं धर्ममूलो नरेन्द्र; राज्यं चेदं धर्ममूलं वदन्ति। धर्मे राजन्वर्तमानः स्वशक्त्या; पुत्रान्सर्वान्पाहि कुन्तीसुतांश्च।
quotes.meaning: Vidura advises Dhritarashtra that the foundation of all governance and life (the threefold path of dharma, artha, and kama) must be rooted in righteousness, and that a king must protect all subjects equally.
quotes.lore_snippet: The wise say a kingdom flourishes only when its ruler upholds dharma above all. As fire cannot burn without fuel, power cannot thrive without justice. Favoritism breeds destruction, while impartiality brings prosperity.

quotes.quote: Surya (to Yudhishthira): Whatever you desire, O king, you shall obtain. I shall provide inexhaustible food for your years in exile—wild fare transformed into sacred sustenance.
quotes.sanskrit: यत्तेऽभिलषितं राजन्सर्वमेतदवाप्स्यसि। अहमन्नं प्रदास्यामि सप्त पञ्च च ते समाः।
quotes.meaning: The sun god Surya blesses Yudhishthira with divine provision, symbolizing that steadfast devotion to duty (dharma) transforms scarcity into abundance.
quotes.lore_snippet: The gods reward those who walk the path of dharma. Even in exile, the righteous find their needs met—for where there is virtue, divine grace follows like shadow follows light.

quotes.quote: Vidura: The highest dharma is for a king to find contentment in his own wealth, not covet others'. Let the Pandavas reclaim what was stolen, lest wrathful Bhima and Arjuna uproot the Kauravas.
quotes.sanskrit: एष धर्मः परमो यत्स्वकेन; राजा तुष्येन्न परस्वेषु गृध्येत्।
quotes.meaning: Vidura warns that greed for others' possessions violates cosmic order, and injustice inevitably provokes destruction from the wronged.
quotes.lore_snippet: History remembers kings not by the gold in their treasuries, but by the justice in their deeds. A throne built on theft becomes a pyre—for even gods cannot extinguish the flames of righteous vengeance.

quotes.quote: Vidura: When truth is spoken but not heeded, like water on a lotus leaf, it slides away, leaving no mark upon the stubborn heart.
quotes.sanskrit: यथा पर्णे पुष्करस्येव सिक्तं जलं न तिष्ठेत्पथ्यमुक्तं तथास्मिन्
quotes.meaning: Even wise counsel falls on deaf ears when the listener is unwilling to change, just as water beads off a lotus leaf without soaking in.
quotes.lore_snippet: The wise say that advice, like rain, must find fertile ground to take root. A closed mind is armor against wisdom, and destiny favors only those who listen.

quotes.quote: A ruler who nurtures allies like embers in ashes shall one day reign alone over the earth, for friendship is the true treasury of kings.
quotes.sanskrit: सं वर्धयन्स्तोकमिवाग्निमात्मवान्स वै भुङ्क्ते पृथिवीमेक एव
quotes.meaning: Strategic patience in cultivating alliances ensures ultimate victory, just as carefully tended coals can reignite a great fire.
quotes.lore_snippet: The Arthashastra teaches that gold buys soldiers, but only shared suffering buys loyalty. The greatest empires are built on the bonds between warriors.

quotes.quote: Dhritarashtra: Where your faith resides, there go without delay. For devotion, not blood, determines true kinship.
quotes.sanskrit: यत्र श्रद्धा भारत तत्र याहि
quotes.meaning: One's chosen path of righteousness matters more than forced familial bonds - follow where your deepest convictions lead.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient scrolls speak of dharma as a path lit from within. When clan and conscience clash, the noble walk alone toward the light.

quotes.quote: Vidura: The wise never forsake their duty, even when faced with life's greatest trials. A righteous mind sees all beings as equal, like the branches of a single tree.
quotes.sanskrit: न जह्याज्जीवितं प्राज्ञस्तं गच्छानय सञ्जय
quotes.meaning: Vidura advises that true wisdom lies in steadfast adherence to duty (dharma) and recognizing the inherent equality of all beings, even in conflict.
quotes.lore_snippet: The sages teach that wisdom is not in cleverness, but in unwavering commitment to righteousness. Like a tree nourishing all its branches, the just see no distinction between kin and foe.

quotes.quote: Dhritarashtra: Even kings drown in darkness when led by attachment. Only by releasing the grip of desire can one see the path of dharma.
quotes.sanskrit: अद्य रात्रौ दिवा चाहं त्वत्कृते भरतर्षभ... प्रजागरे पपश्यामि विचित्रं देहमात्मनः
quotes.meaning: The blind king confesses how his paternal attachment clouds his judgment, illustrating how desire obscures moral clarity.
quotes.lore_snippet: As a lotus must rise above the mud to bloom, so must the mind transcend personal attachments to perceive truth. The wise warn that love unchecked becomes a cage of shadows.

quotes.quote: Shakuni: Deceit wears the mask of strategy, but time reveals all falsehoods. Even the cleverest gambler cannot escape the reckoning of karma.
quotes.sanskrit: गतास्ते समयं कृत्वा नैतदेवं भविष्यति
quotes.meaning: Shakuni's manipulative counsel exposes how short-term cunning ultimately unravels when opposed to cosmic justice.
quotes.lore_snippet: Dice may fall as the thrower wishes, but the universe keeps its own tally. What begins in shadows must eventually stand in sunlight - this is the law of the Three Worlds.

quotes.quote: Vyasa: The wise see the future, but fools walk blindly into the flames of their own making.
quotes.sanskrit: प्रज्ञाचक्षुषमासीनमुवाचाभ्येत्य सत्वरः
quotes.meaning: Vyasa warns Dhritarashtra that his son Duryodhana's hatred for the Pandavas will lead to destruction, urging him to act with wisdom before it's too late.
quotes.lore_snippet: The seers of old often spoke of the 'eye of wisdom'—the ability to foresee the consequences of one's actions. Those who ignore such visions court disaster, as the Kauravas learned too late.

quotes.quote: Dhritarashtra: A father's love blinds even the wisest to the faults of his sons.
quotes.sanskrit: पुत्रस्नेहेन भगवञ्जानन्नपि यतव्रत
quotes.meaning: Dhritarashtra admits his inability to restrain Duryodhana despite knowing his evil intentions, illustrating how parental attachment can override wisdom.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient scrolls tell of King Dhritarashtra, whose love for his son outweighed his duty as ruler. This weakness doomed his lineage—a reminder that even kings kneel before affection's thrall.

quotes.quote: Surabhi: The strong bear the world's weight, while the weak break beneath their own sorrow.
quotes.sanskrit: एकस्तत्र बलोपेतो धुरमुद्वहतेऽधिकाम्
quotes.meaning: The celestial cow Surabhi laments how the mighty endure greater burdens while the feeble suffer disproportionately—a metaphor for cosmic imbalance.
quotes.lore_snippet: The weeping of Surabhi echoes in every age: the oxen of fate pull heavier loads than they can bear, while the privileged ride untouched. Thus spoke the sages of inequality's toll.

quotes.quote: Dhritarashtra: A father's love blinds him to his son's faults, yet duty demands he correct them before the world does.
quotes.sanskrit: यदि पार्थिव कौरव्याञ्जीवमानानिहेच्छसि दुर्योधनस्तव सुतः शमं गच्छतु पाण्डवैः
quotes.meaning: Dhritarashtra acknowledges his inability to discipline Duryodhana despite knowing his wickedness, showing the conflict between paternal love and royal duty.
quotes.lore_snippet: Kings and commoners alike face the test of balancing affection with justice. The wise know that unchecked favoritism breeds destruction, while measured discipline preserves legacies.

quotes.quote: Vyasa: When wise counsel is ignored, the seeds of wrath take root - for every unheeded warning, a curse grows in the hearts of sages.
quotes.sanskrit: ब्रूयाद्यदेष राजेन्द्र तत्कार्यमविशङ्कया अक्रियायां हि कार्यस्य पुत्रं ते शप्स्यते रुषा
quotes.meaning: Vyasa warns Dhritarashtra that failure to act on sage advice will provoke divine retribution, showing karma's inevitable workings.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient texts speak of 'brahmarishi kopam' - the terrible wrath of enlightened ones. Their curses manifest not from malice, but as cosmic corrections for dharma's violation.

quotes.quote: Dhritarashtra: The pride of the wicked bears fruit swiftly, and their downfall is certain as the sun’s rise.
quotes.sanskrit: यस्मात्त्वं मामनादृत्य नेमां वाचं चिकीर्षसि तस्मादस्याभिमानस्य सद्यः फलमवाप्नुहि
quotes.meaning: Dhritarashtra warns that arrogance and disregard for wisdom lead to immediate consequences, foreshadowing Duryodhana's eventual defeat.
quotes.lore_snippet: Pride is the shadow of folly, and the unwise who walk in its shade shall find their path ends at the cliff's edge. Even kings are not spared the weight of their own hubris.

quotes.quote: Maitreya: When a son ignores wisdom, his fate is written in the ashes of his own choices.
quotes.sanskrit: न ते शुश्रूषते सुतः एष ते विदुरः सर्वमाख्यास्यति गते मयि
quotes.meaning: Maitreya declares that those who reject counsel invite destruction, leaving their legacy to be recounted by others.
quotes.lore_snippet: To scorn the words of sages is to kindle one’s own pyre. The deafest ears belong to those who fall the hardest.

quotes.quote: The demon Kirmira’s roar shook the forest, but courage stands unmoved even when the earth trembles.
quotes.sanskrit: तस्य नादेन सन्त्रस्ताः पक्षिणः सर्वतोदिशम्
quotes.meaning: Despite the terror sown by Kirmira’s wrath, true resolve remains steadfast against overwhelming darkness.
quotes.lore_snippet: Fear may scatter the weak like leaves in a storm, but the righteous stand rooted as ancient trees—unbroken, unshaken.

quotes.quote: Yudhishthira: Even in exile, a righteous man carries his dharma like a lamp in darkness, for virtue cannot be stripped by circumstance.
quotes.sanskrit: धर्म एव हतो हन्ति धर्मो रक्षति रक्षितः
quotes.meaning: Dharma (righteousness) protects those who uphold it, even in adversity. Yudhishthira embodies this by maintaining his principles while exiled in the forest.
quotes.lore_snippet: The sages teach that dharma is both shield and compass. A traveler who walks its path may lose his way, but never his honor—for the earth itself bends to uphold the virtuous.

quotes.quote: Bhima: Strength without restraint is like a river without banks—it floods the very land it meant to nourish.
quotes.sanskrit: बलं हि निर्बन्धनं नश्यति
quotes.meaning: Bhima's battle with Kirmira demonstrates how raw power must be tempered by wisdom, lest it becomes self-destructive.
quotes.lore_snippet: Warriors of old knew this truth: the mightiest sword kept in its scabbard strikes truest when drawn. Unchecked fury burns the wielder first.

quotes.quote: Kirmira: Hatred is a fire fed by memory—until nothing remains but the ashes of one's own soul.
quotes.sanskrit: द्वेषोऽग्निः स्मृतिहविषा
quotes.meaning: The demon Kirmira's undying vengeance for Bhima's past deeds consumes him, illustrating how obsession with revenge leads to self-destruction.
quotes.lore_snippet: The Rakshasa clans carved this warning in blood: he who digs a grave for his enemy often falls into it himself.

quotes.quote: Vasudeva: Duryodhana, Karna, Shakuni, and the wicked Duhshasana—the earth shall drink their blood. This is the eternal law of justice.
quotes.sanskrit: दुर्योधनस्य कर्णस्य शकुनेश्च दुरात्मनः। दुःशासनचतुर्थानां भूमिः पास्यति शोणितम्॥
quotes.meaning: Krishna declares that evildoers will face inevitable retribution, emphasizing that cosmic justice (dharma) will prevail over tyranny.
quotes.lore_snippet: The wise know that no act of adharma escapes the scales of time. When tyrants spill blood unjustly, the earth herself thirsts to restore balance.

quotes.quote: Yudhishthira's allies gathered like storms, asking: 'What shall we do?' For even in exile, the righteous inspire loyalty against oppression.
quotes.sanskrit: गर्हयन्तो धार्तराष्ट्रान्किं कुर्म इति चाब्रुवन्॥
quotes.meaning: The collective resolve of allies demonstrates that dharma attracts support even in adversity, while tyranny breeds condemnation.
quotes.lore_snippet: A king's true strength lies not in his throne, but in the hearts of those who stand with him unbidden when darkness falls.

quotes.quote: Krishna: He who hates you hates me, and he who follows you follows me. There is no difference between us.
quotes.sanskrit: यस्त्वां द्वेष्टि स मां द्वेष्टि यस्त्वामनु स मामनु
quotes.meaning: This profound statement by Krishna to Arjuna illustrates the divine unity between the seeker and the Supreme. It teaches that devotion to God manifests through love for His devotees.
quotes.lore_snippet: The sages say that to serve a true devotee is to serve the Divine itself. Just as a river merges with the ocean, the lover of God becomes one with the Beloved.

quotes.quote: Krishna: You are me, and I am you. What is mine is yours, and what is yours is mine. No mortal can discern where one ends and the other begins.
quotes.sanskrit: ममैव त्वं तवैवाहं ये मदीयास्तवैव ते
quotes.meaning: Krishna reveals the ultimate truth of non-duality - the complete dissolution of boundaries between the Divine and the surrendered soul.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient scriptures compare this union to salt dissolving in water - the devotee retains individual form yet becomes inseparable from the Divine essence in substance.

quotes.quote: Krishna: I am the beginning, the end, and the eternal sacrifice. All worlds rest within me as pearls strung upon a thread.
quotes.sanskrit:
क्षेत्रज्ञः सर्वभूतानामादिरन्तश्च केशव
निधानं तपसां कृष्ण यज्ञस्त्वं च सनातनः
quotes.meaning: Krishna declares His omnipresence as the source, sustainer, and ultimate destination of all existence, with creation unfolding within His cosmic being.
quotes.lore_snippet: The wise see the universe as the Divine body - galaxies His breath, stars His thoughts, and time the rhythm of His heartbeat.

quotes.quote: Draupadi: Where husbands fail to protect their wives, even their strength and bows are but an illusion.
quotes.sanskrit: धिग्बलं भीमसेनस्य धिक्पार्थस्य धनुष्मताम्
quotes.meaning: Draupadi condemns empty valor when fundamental duties (like spousal protection) are abandoned. True strength lies in upholding dharma, not mere physical power.
quotes.lore_snippet: The Scrolls of the East teach: A warrior's might means nothing if he cannot shield his hearth. The Pandavas' failure to intervene when Draupadi was disrobed became their greatest moral trial.

quotes.quote: Through the wife's protection flows the safeguarding of progeny, and through progeny's protection, the soul itself is preserved.
quotes.sanskrit:
भार्यायां रक्ष्यमाणायां प्रजा भवति रक्षिता
प्रजायां रक्ष्यमाणायामात्मा भवति रक्षितः
quotes.meaning: This concentric philosophy reveals societal stability begins with protecting women - the foundation of family, lineage, and ultimately one's spiritual legacy.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient Nymphs of Wisdom whisper: Civilizations crumble when women's dignity is violated. As the hearth-fire guards the home, so must kings guard justice's first flame.

quotes.quote: Bhima: Fear not, for I shall strike like Garuda upon serpents - no danger shall touch you while breath remains in me.
quotes.sanskrit:
वैनतेयो यथा पक्षी गरुडः पततां वरः
तथैवाभिपतिष्यामि भयं वो नेह विद्यते
quotes.meaning: Bhima vows divine-level protection, channeling Garuda's mythic might. Contrasts his earlier inaction with now awakened righteous fury.
quotes.lore_snippet: Warrior-poets sing: When Bhima finally awoke to his dharma, his wrath shook the earth. Like the sun dispelling night, true protectors act without hesitation.

quotes.quote: Krishna: Even if the heavens fall or the Himalayas crumble, my word shall never prove false.
quotes.sanskrit:
पतेद्द्यौर्हिमवाञ्शीर्येत्पृथिवी शकलीभवेत्
शुष्येत्तोयनिधिः कृष्णे न मे मोघं वचो भवेत्
quotes.meaning: Krishna affirms the absolute truth of his promise, stating that cosmic destruction would occur before his words would fail.
quotes.lore_snippet: The wise know that a promise from the divine is more enduring than mountains. When Lord Krishna gives his word, even time itself bends to fulfill it.

quotes.quote: Dhrishtadyumna: With Krishna as our refuge, we are invincible - what are Dhritarashtra's sons compared to even Indra's enemies?
quotes.sanskrit:
रामकृष्णौ व्यपाश्रित्य अजेयाः स्म शुचिस्मिते
अपि वृत्रहणा युद्धे किं पुनर्धृतराष्ट्रजैः
quotes.meaning: Expressing supreme confidence in divine protection, suggesting mortal enemies pale before those sheltered by the divine.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient warriors knew that true strength comes not from weapons alone, but from righteous alignment with cosmic forces. Divine favor makes the weak mighty.

quotes.quote: Krishna warns of four vices that destroy kings: gambling, hunting, drinking, and lust for women.
quotes.sanskrit:
स्त्रियोऽक्षा मृगया पानमेतत्कामसमुत्थितम्
व्यसनं चतुष्टयं प्रोक्तं यै राजन्भ्रश्यते श्रियः
quotes.meaning: A timeless warning about the destructive vices that lead rulers to ruin, given as prophetic advice to prevent the Kuru downfall.
quotes.lore_snippet: The scrolls of governance warn that a throne stands on four pillars of restraint. Remove one, and the kingdom begins its inevitable collapse.

quotes.quote: Krishna: By truth I wield my weapons, and by truth I shall not return until I have slain the wicked who betray trust and bring ruin upon the innocent.
quotes.sanskrit: सत्येनायुधमालभे... अहत्वा न निवर्तिष्ये
quotes.meaning: Krishna declares his unwavering commitment to justice, vowing to destroy evil forces (like Shalva) who violate dharma through treachery, even at personal cost.
quotes.lore_snippet: The wise know that true warriors bind their weapons with oaths, not just steel. When a champion swears by truth itself, their blows carry the weight of cosmic law.

quotes.quote: The rage of the dishonored transforms even kings into storms of destruction—but only the disciplined become instruments of divine retribution.
quotes.sanskrit: रोषवशसम्प्राप्तो... दुरात्मवान्
quotes.meaning: Both Shalva (driven by vengeance for Shishupala's death) and Krishna channel wrath, but Krishna's is tempered by dharma, making his violence righteous.
quotes.lore_snippet: Fire consumes indiscriminately, while the smith's forge shapes destiny. So too does uncontrolled anger destroy, but focused fury serves cosmic balance.

quotes.quote: Krishna: The fortress of the wise is built not with walls of stone, but with vigilance and discipline.
quotes.sanskrit: प्रमादं परिरक्षद्भिरुग्रसेनोद्धवादिभिः
quotes.meaning: True protection comes from constant awareness and strategic preparation, not just physical defenses.
quotes.lore_snippet: Ancient texts speak of cities that stood unconquered not by their height, but by the unbroken watchfulness of their guardians. Even the mightiest walls crumble when vigilance sleeps.

quotes.quote: The disciplined army knows no deserters, for loyalty is the true wages of war.
quotes.sanskrit: न कुप्यवेतनी कश्चिन्न चातिक्रान्तवेतनी
quotes.meaning: An army bound by duty and proper compensation fights as one, without betrayal or abandonment.
quotes.lore_snippet: Mercenaries may fight for gold, but legends are written by those who serve with honor. The chronicles of Dwarka tell of warriors who valued their oaths more than their lives.
